utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Hey, Leonard, check this out.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Leonard, she’s doing it again.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I think it upsets Sheldon when you play with the food.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No. It upsets Sheldon when she willy-nilly takes it from the containers without regard for its equitable distribution. This is essentially why you have famine in India.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: You want me to put it back?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Leonard.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: It upsets Sheldon when you play with the Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Howard (arriving)
utterance.content: What’s up, my nerdizzles? Raj, Sheldon, I want you to meet my girlfriend Bernadette.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Hello.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Leonard, Penny, you know my girlfriend Bernadette.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah. Hey.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Bernadette, say fo’shizzle to my nerdizzles.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: I don’t think I can. I don’t have Howard’s street cred.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I hope it’s all right, I told my girlfriend Bernadette she could join us for dinner.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sure. The more, the merrier.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Wait, no, that’s a false equivalency. More does not equal merry. If there were 2,000 people in this apartment right now, would we be celebrating? No, we’d be suffocating.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sheldon…

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Don’t Sheldon me. We ordered for five people, not six.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, come on, it’s fine. We’ll just put it all on the table, you know, family style.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, sure. And while we’re at it, why don’t we put our hands behind our backs, have an old-fashioned eating contest?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Relax, it’ll be fine, sit down, you guys.

utterance.speaker: Everyone
utterance.content: NO!

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, yeah, you can’t sit there.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Why not?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: That’s where Sheldon sits.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: He can’t sit somewhere else?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh no, no, you see, in the winter, that seat is close enough to the radiator so that he’s warm, yet not so close that he sweats. In the summer, it’s directly in the path of a cross-breeze created by opening windows there and there. It faces the television at an angle that isn’t direct, so he can still talk to everybody, yet not so wide that the picture looks distorted.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Perhaps there’s hope for you after all.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Ooh, I love your shoes.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, thanks. They are cute, aren’t they?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Where’d you get them?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Shoes for Less.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: I’ve been meaning to go over there.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, great selection, great prices.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: My mother was right. Hell is real.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Come on, Sheldon. let the womenfolk chat.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Womenfolk?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Gals? Chicks? Utero-Americans?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Just eat your dinner.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Don’t take him too seriously, a lot of what he says is intended as humour.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah, well, I don’t think it’s very funny.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Me neither, but he just lights up when I laugh.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Howard, never let her go.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: So, Leonard, Howard says you’re working on fundamental tests of quantum mechanics.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I am. Are you interested in physics?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Oh, I find it fascinating. If I hadn’t gone into microbiology, I probably would have gone into physics. Or ice dancing.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Actually, my tests of the Aharonov-Bohm quantum interference effect have reached an interesting point. Right now, we’re testing the phase shift due to an electric potential.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: That’s amazing.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yes. Leonard’s work is nearly as amazing as third graders growing lima beans in wet paper towels. While I appreciate the oh, snap, I’m uncomfortable having your moist breath in my ear.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Are you going to try to set up the voltages using tunnel junctions?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yes, I am. You want to see a simulation on my laptop?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Oh, yeah, show me. In microbiology, the most exciting thing I get to work with is yeast.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Howard?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yeah?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Your shoes are delightful. Where did you get them?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Bazinga. I don’t care.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Ha! Eat my dust, racially stereotypical plumber.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: That’s not fair. I got stuck behind a tree.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: And a cow and a penguin. Face it dude, whether it’s a real car or a virtual cartoon car, you can’t drive.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Just need a little more practice.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: What you need is cheat codes, motor skills and a magic genie who grants wishes to little boys who suck at Mario Kart.

utterance.speaker: Penny (knocking and entering)
utterance.content: Hey, Sheldon, can I talk to you for a second?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It’s not about shoes, is it? I don’t think I could go through that again.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: It’s not about shoes.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Then speak.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Um, actually, can we do it in private?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: All right. Go away. I agree, it’s rude, but she asked for privacy.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Thanks, Raj. Okay, so here’s the thing, I was wondering if you could maybe teach me a little physics?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: A little physics? There’s no such thing. Physics encompasses the entire universe, from quantum particles to supernovas, from spinning electrons to spinning galaxies.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah, okay, cool. I don’t need the PBS special, I just want to know enough so I can talk to Leonard about his job. You know, like Bernadette does.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Why can’t Leonard teach you?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: ‘Cause I want to surprise him.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Can’t you surprise him in some other way? For example, I’m sure he’d be delightfully taken aback if you cleaned your apartment.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Come on, Sheldon, this is important to me.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Penny, this would be a massive undertaking, and my time is both limited and valuable.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: You’re sitting here playing video games all day.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Okay, point. What sort of foundation do you have? Did you take any science classes in school?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sure. I did the one with the frogs.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: The one with the frogs.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah, actually, it was pretty cool. A lot of the girls threw up, but I gutted that thing like a deer.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m sorry, Penny, I don’t think so.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, come on! A smart guy like you, it’ll be a challenge. You can make it like an experiment.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Interesting. I suppose if someone could teach sign language to KoKo the gorilla, I could teach you some rudimentary physics.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Great! It’s a little insulting, but great. I’ll be KoKo.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Not likely. KoKo learned to understand over 2,000 words, not one of which had anything to do with shoes.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Hey, fellas. This is my girlfriend Bernadette. My girlfriend Bernadette.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Who are all those people?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Have no idea. Hey, Leonard.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Hi.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hey, look, it’s Howard and his girlfriend Bernadette.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Thought I’d give the little woman a tour of the old salt mines.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: He doesn’t mean salt mines. He means where he works.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah, no, I got it.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: So, how’s your experiment going?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Ah, terrific. We’re getting the electron accelerator set up. We should be ready to go day after tomorrow.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Boy, I’d love to see that.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You’re welcome to come.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Really? Oh, that’d be great. How exciting is that?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Like Hanukkah in July.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Do they have that?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Oh. You got me again. This isn’t non-fat yogurt, this is fatty fat fat. Excuse me.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Could you grab me another napkin, sweetie?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Sure.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Thanks, honey. All right, what is your deal?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Excuse me?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Inviting my girlfriend to come see your electron accelerator?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah? So?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Wow! You really are a piece of work. It’s not enough you get the prom queen, you have to get the head of the decorating committee, too?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What are you talking about?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Don’t play innocent with me. I practically invented using fancy lab equipment to seduce women.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Has it ever worked?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Not so far, but that’s not the point!

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Howard, relax, I’m not interested in your girlfriend.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I hope not, because you don’t want to mess with me. I’m crazy.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I believe you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Research journal, entry one. I’m about to embark on one of the great challenges of my scientific career, teaching Penny physics. I’m calling it Project Gorilla.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Hey, Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Come in. Take a seat. Subject has arrived. I’ve extended a friendly casual greeting.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Ready to get started?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: One moment. Subject appears well-rested and enthusiastic. Apparently, ignorance is bliss. All right, let us begin. Where’s your notebook?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Um, I don’t have one.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: How are you going to take notes without a notebook?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I have to take notes?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: How else are you gonna study for the tests?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: There’s gonna be a test?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Tests. Here. It’s college-ruled. I hope that’s not too intimidating.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You’re welcome. Now, Introduction to Physics. What is physics? Physics comes from the ancient Greek word physika. It’s at this point that you’ll want to start taking notes. Physika means the science of natural things. And it is there, in ancient Greece, that our story begins.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Ancient Greece?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Hush. If you have questions, raise your hand. It’s a warm summer evening, circa 600 BC, you’ve finished your shopping at the local market, or agora, and you look up at the night sky. There you notice some of the stars seem to move, so you name them planetes, or wanderer. Yes, Penny?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Um, does this have anything to do with Leonard’s work?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: This is the beginning of a twenty six hundred year journey we’re going to take together from the ancient Greeks through Isaac Newton to Niels Bohr to Erwin Schrodinger to the Dutch researchers that Leonard is currently ripping off.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Twenty six hundred years?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yeah, give or take. As I was saying, it’s a warm summer evening in ancient Greece… Yes, Penny?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I have to go to the bathroom.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Can’t you hold it?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Not for twenty six hundred years.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Project Gorilla, entry two. I am exhausted.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Howard?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Huh?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: It unhooks in the front.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh, that explains a lot.

utterance.speaker: Howard’s Mother
utterance.content: Howard, I’m home!

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Of course.

utterance.speaker: Howard’s Mother
utterance.content: Senior fitness was cancelled. It turns out you can forget how to ride a bike. I’m fine, but, oy, did Sam Harpootian eat gravel.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: That’s great, Ma!

utterance.speaker: Howard’s Mother
utterance.content: What’s great about an 80-year-old Armenian man with half his chin scraped off?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: I guess I should go.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: No, no, don’t move. Hey, Ma, can I have lamb stew for dinner?

utterance.speaker: Howard’s Mother
utterance.content: Lamb stew? I’d have to go to the supermarket.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Please? I got a real hankering.

utterance.speaker: Howard’s Mother
utterance.content: Oh, I can’t say no to my little tushy face. I’ll be back soon.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Thanks, Ma.

utterance.speaker: Howard’s Mother
utterance.content: Do you want the regular peas or the Le Seur?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Always Le Seur peas with lamb stew!

utterance.speaker: Howard’s Mother
utterance.content: You’re right! When you’re right, you’re right! What if they’re out of the Le Seur?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Then get the regular!

utterance.speaker: Howard’s Mother
utterance.content: All right! You don’t have to yell!

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Sorry about that.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette (her phone chimes)
utterance.content: Let me just put that on vibrate.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I’m already on vibrate.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: You know, that one I got. Howard, did you say something to Leonard about me?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Uh, what do you mean?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: He says if I go see his experiment tomorrow it might weird you out.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Really? He said that?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: You’re not jealous of Leonard, are you?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Me? No. I may have mentioned that it’s a little inappropriate to be asking another man’s girlfriend to his experiment without first discussing it with said man.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Are you saying I need to ask your permission to hang out with Leonard?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I didn’t say anything like that. I said Leonard has to ask my permission. Come on, I don’t want to eat lamb stew with my mother. Damn, I was this close on the bra.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Now, remember, Newton realized that Aristotle was wrong and force was not necessary to maintain motion. So let’s plug in our 9.8 meters per second squared as A and we get force, Earth gravity, equals mass times 9.8 meters per second per second. So we can see that MA equals MG and what do we know from this?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Uh, we know that… Newton was a really smart cookie. Oh! Is that where Fig Newtons come from?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, Fig Newtons are named after a small town in Massachusetts. Don’t write that down!

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sorry.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Now, if MA equals MG what does that imply?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I don’t know.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: How can you not know? I just told you. Have you suffered a recent blow to the head?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Hey! You don’t have to be so mean!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m sorry. Have you suffered a recent blow to the head?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: No, you just suck at teaching.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Really? Of those two explanations, which one seems the most likely?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, God, Sheldon, look I’m trying to understand, but you’re going too fast. Can you just back up a little bit?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: All right. It’s a warm summer evening in ancient Greece…

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Not that far back!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Okay! At what point did you begin to feel lost?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I don’t know. Where were we looking up at the night sky?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Greece.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Damn it!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: There’s no need to get frustrated, people learn at different rates. Unlike objects falling in a vacuum, which…? MA equals MG?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Squared?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Aristotle?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Five?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh!

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Then I don’t know.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Why are you crying?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Because I’m stupid!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: That’s no reason to cry. One cries because one is sad. For example, I cry because others are stupid and it makes me sad.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, look, can we just please forget about all this extra stuff and can you just tell me what Leonard does?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: All right. Leonard is attempting to learn why sub-atomic particles move the way they do.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Really? That’s it? Well, that doesn’t sound so complicated.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It’s not. That’s why Leonard does it.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, I just have one question. What exactly are sub-atomic particles?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: A good question.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: And to answer it, we first must ask ourselves, what is physics?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, balls.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It’s a warm summer evening in ancient Greece…

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Okay, I got a bone to pick with you.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What did I do now?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I was in bed with Bernadette, and you text-blocked me.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: We were completely naked, about to devour each other when, you text her that I have a problem with her hanging out with you.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You do have a problem with her hanging out with me.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yeah, but that’s not what you tell her.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What was I supposed to tell her?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I don’t know, something that doesn’t make me come off as a petty, jealous douche.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: And what would that be?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Come on, do I have to think of everything?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Hey, Leonard. Am I too late to see the experiment? Oh, hi.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Hi.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: What are you doing here?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Same thing you’re doing here. I came to see Leonard’s experiment.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: No, you didn’t. You said Leonard’s experiment was stupid.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You told her my experiment was stupid?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I was just repeating what Sheldon said. Let’s not get off topic, Bernadette, I need to apologize. I was wrong to tell you who you should be friends with.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Should I, um, leave you two alone?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: No, Leonard, you should hear this.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, good, ’cause I wasn’t really gonna go.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Look, I know I come off as confident and worldly, but the truth is I’m not.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: We’re shocked.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Which is why I tend to feel threatened by other guys.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Or loud noises, clowns and nuns.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: But I now realize how foolish that is.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: He had a panic attack once when he got his head stuck in a sweater.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: It was a full turtleneck. Why aren’t you helping me?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I don’t know. Maybe because I’m crazy?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Bernadette, please, I’m asking you to give me another chance.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: What do you think, Leonard? Should I give him another chance?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: It’s up to you. He didn’t call your experiment stupid.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Come here, tushy face.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Tushy face, that is going on Twitter right now.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Raj, you should’ve seen Leonard’s experiment. The interference pattern was so cool when the electron beam was on.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I’m glad you enjoyed it. Most people aren’t that interested in what I do.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Actually, that’s not true, Leonard. In fact, recently I’ve been thinking that given the parameters of your experiment, the transport of electrons through the aperture the nano-fabricated metal rings is qualitatively no different than the experiment already conducted in the Netherlands. Their observed phase shift in the diffusing electrons inside the metal ring already conclusively demonstrated the electric analogue of the Aharonov-Bohm quantum-interference effect. That’s it. That’s all I know. Oh, wait! Fig Newtons were named after a town in Massachusetts, not the scientist.
